Doris Miller should have received the Medal of Honor. He put his life on the line for a country that treated him like a second-class citizen. We can, and we must correct this injustice by awarding him the Medal of Honor posthumously.

In January of 2020, the Secretary of the Navy announced the naming of a future aircraft carrier in his honor—the U.S.S Doris Miller (CVN-81). It is the first aircraft carrier named for an enlisted sailor and African American. This was a massive step forward, but it is not enough. https://t.co/kbc2Q6GHUT

Two years later, Doris Miller was aboard on the U.S.S. Liscome Bay when it was struck by a torpedo off the coast of Butaritari Island in the Western Pacific. He and over 600 other sailors onboard the ship were presumed dead and their bodies were never recovered.

But when the time came for official recognition, Miller, who was listed as an “unnamed Negro,” received only a letter of commendation while 15 of his shipmates received the Medal of Honor. It wasn’t until the NAACP requested proper recognition that he was awarded the Navy Cross. https://t.co/G9WgS9GkXG

Per the U.S.S. West Virginia’s action report, Miller was “instrumental in hauling people along through oil and water to the quarterdeck, thereby unquestionably saving the lives of a number of people who might otherwise have been lost.”

When the attack began, he immediately left his post in the laundry room to rescue shipmates injured in the initial barrage and to defend the harbor. He is credited for manning an anti-aircraft gun, for which he had no training, and providing cover fire until ordered off the ship. https://t.co/PAbwaHjJ30

Doris Miller was born in Waco, Texas in 1919. After high school, he enlisted in the Navy as a mess attendant—one of the few positions available for Black sailors. He was assigned to the U.S.S. West Virginia, which was stationed at Pearl Harbor the morning of December 7th, 1941.

Today marks the 80th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor. More than 2,400 lives were lost, and our nation was forever changed.

Many heroes were made on that fateful day, but let me tell you the story of one you may not have heard of before—Doris Miller. https://t.co/Ft02FATh1v

@JeffFortenberry This bipartisan bill would require all hotels and places of short-term lodging to advertise a price that includes all mandatory fees. This applies to online travel agents and short-term rental sites as well. #EndHiddenFees
